Dear Mr. Harrison, Thank you for your letter of the 29th November, received yesterday, with its enclosed cheque. Yours sincerely, F.A.K.Harrison Hsq., India u ffice, Whitehall, S.W.l.V* t V PERSONAL 149, KINGS#AP, PETT3 WOOD, 22nd April, 1943. Dear Peel, I want to make an effort to retain one of my two remaining lady Assistants; in fact, they are the only Assistants I have left now. Both are proficient and trustworthy. The younger one, who is now 23, has been with me for five years and the elder one has been with me for 20 years. The Ministry of Labour now want the younger one. I cannot possibly get anyone to take the place of either. My work, as representing the Bahrein Company and in connection with the Near Eastern Interests of the Standard and Texas Companies is, of course,extremely confidential and I must run no risk of anything I do getting beyond the office. along and talk to you or Lumby if either one of you could spare me half an hour for the purpose. It will mean, I think, a recommendation being made either by your Department or by the Petroleum Department to the Ministry of Labour & National Service. That recommendation seems to rest, in turn, upon my representation that urgent work in which a Government Department is interested, would be seriously curtailed (the language is that of the Form N.S.247 of the Ministry of Labour & National Service, not mine). I understand that the machinery for intervention by the Petroleum Concerns is involved. I could, of course, have a chat with Starling about the matter either before or after see ing you or Lumby. I was wondering if you could help me in this. I could come 3.T.Peel Ksq., C.B.E., M.C., India Office, Whitehall, S.VJ.l.

mods.abstract: The file comprises personal correspondence between Mr H R Ballantyne, agent of the Bahrain Petroleum Company Limited, and Roland Tennyson Peel, India Office, regarding the matter of Ballantyne's personal assistants.
